bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 23, 1941

div1.p: Kean comments on the controversy over Agramonte's role in the mosquito work. He answers, in detail, questions based on Hench's reading of Kean's diary. He emphasizes that Reed never told him Lazear's infection was experimental. He believes Lazear's careful records enabled Reed to understand the yellow fever incubation period.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 23, 1941
div1.opener:
In re Y. F. Episode
Page 1-
2804 N St. Washington
January 23- 1941
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
It was very considerate of you to send a carbon
copy of your letter for convenience in replying and
I am going to show some consideration on my side-
In the first place as you have to read my letters in
long hand I will try to write clearly- Then I have
been thinking what a mass of M. S. S. you are
accumulating and the trouble I must give in
the filing of my little note-paper sheets- I have
found some paper therefore just the size of your
letter-paper and will use that here after in my
replies- I find that the space between your ques-
tions is not sufficient to answer some of them &,
for some, explanations are necessary, I will use my
letter space for these and refer to them by writing in
the questionnaire see letter p -- or in this see 2#

I am much interested in them and in seeing how closely
you had read the diary which skips from one thing to
another continually- It is like the old woman who tried
to improve her education by reading the dictionary- She
said it would be very interesting if it didnt change
the subject so often-

I am much interested in the defense of Agramonte
which you have made in your letter to Gen. Truby of
Jan 7th As you know the statement that Agramonte had
no part in the mosquito work on page 21 of the Surgeon General's
Y. F. Episode
Page 2
Statement in the Senate Doc. Yellow Fever was based on infor-
mation given me by Carroll- When Agramonte saw it, he
complained that it had done him great injustice- So I
asked him to prepare his own statement which was published
over his own certificate on pages 25 and 26 of the same
compilation- My good friend Gen. Truby criticised this
as inaccurate and reproached Gen. Ireland and
me in a letter last year for letting it be published
over the Surgeon General's signature- As I was occupied
with other matters and the operations of the Board as regard
these details were not within my knowledge, I do not
feel able to pass judgment in the matter- I have always
felt however that I had done Agramonte an injustice in
accepting Carroll's statement, without verifying it, and I
was glad to be able to give equal publicity to Agramonte's
statement-

Now taking up your questions: Dr. Echevarria was called
major but whether that was a U. S. Army volunteer title I am not sure-
He had at one time been employed as a medical officer by
the spaniards and was, when we went to Cuba, employed
by our army- Gen. OReilly (then Col & Chief Surgeon of our forces in Cuba)
had a very high opinion of him- Just how he had a hand
in the San Josè negociation I do not know- I suppose he
was recommended to Major Reed as a reliable man-

I cannot give you any assistance with miss Agramonte's
photographs- There were a lot of those small buildings
at the old Spanish Military Hospital which we took over and called
Military Hospital No. 1- Now as to the diary questions:
# 1- I was put in command of the 2nd Division Hospital of
Y. F. Episode
Page 3
the 7th Corp of Camp Cuba Libre. Jacksonville
Fla, as it was much the largest medical unit there, and
the preceding Commanding Officer Major Edward Bokaman
of St. Paul, an able surgeon, but ignorant of Army hospital
administration, recommended it- My rank was Major & Surgeon
of Volunteers- My actual rank in the regular medical Corps was
Captain- I was called major except for the brief period that I was
Chief Surgeon 7th Army Corps when I was Lt. Col. of Vols-
# 2 I first met Major Reed in July 1906 when I was the
Medical Officer at Key West Barracks- He came down
and spent a week with me as my guest- His errand
was to study certain ameboid bodies which he had
found in the blood of negroes and monkeys after
vaccination- There was an epidemic of small pox in
Key West at that time & he wanted to search for this
organism in the blood of small pox patients- He was
a most delightful guest, full of quaint stories and
a very whimsical humor- I had spent two days at his
house in Georgetown, Washington D. C. when I was en route to
Boston in 1897. Then I was him at Jacksonville in 1898.
# 3. I think you saw the photograph of this 1st Division Hospital
you know there are 3 divisions of Infanty in each corp, or
there were at that time, and 3 regiments in each brigade, 3 bri-
gades in each division- But many regiments had been mus-
tered out & did not come to Cuba- So we established only the
1st Division Hospital for the 7th Corps at Camp Columbia-
# 4 Yes-
# 5 Mil. Hosp. No. 1 as I recollect was a big rambling group of low
Y. F. Episode
Page 4
buildings. You may have seen two pictures from different points
of view. of this much spread out hospital-
# 6- and # 18- # 18 I am not surprised that you are puzzled at the ap-
pearances and disappearances of Major Reed- He was as you say
the “trouble shooter” of the Medical Dept- the ablest epidemiologist
and bacteriologist we had and Gen. Sternberg, who was the pioneer
in bacteriology probably in the U. S., had complete confidence in him-
As regards letters I have very few long-hand letters of Reed and they
are about personal matters, I have given away most of those that
touched on his work, as Mrs. Reed tells me she has, to institutions
& writers- My typed letters- written (carbons) and letters received went
in the files- I usually had a separate personal file and some of
these I still have & will fix a time to look over. Many I should
burn: I will remember you when I do this and save what you
can use- I dont think you can get anything out of the Surgeon
General's Office. They are overwhelmed with current work now
on account of the creation of a great army- Besides the records
of 40 years ago are like the snows of yesteryear- If not destroyed
they are buried under the vast accumulations of the world War-
# 7. When the 7th Army Corps arrived in Cuba in Dec. 1898 they
went into camp at Marianao- Quemados where the Military City
is now & Gen. Lee's tent Hdqrs was at the N-E end of the camp
near where was the station of Buena Vista on the narrow - guage R. R. from
Havana- He moved from his tent into the Toledo palace, as it was
called then, on May 13- 1900- see answer to # 17-
# 8- see #18 below-
# 9. Yes-
# 10- I suppose Reed's report of his inspection of the outbreak of
fever at Camaguey went into the files of the Surg. Gen.'s Office
Y. F. Episode-
Page 5
see remarks on files S. G. O. at end of #6 above- There may have been
a sentence or two of reference to it in the S. G.s Annual Report for 1900 but
the Report of Reed was not printed I am sure-
# 11- Yes
# 12- I dont think he saw any cases of y. f. on his short visits to
Cuba in March 1900 and May 1900- Reed was not in Cuba in July 1899
In my Entry of July 17, 1899 you misread Peed for Reed- Capt-
George P. Peed was a regular Med Officer on duty at Columbia Bks then-
= 13 # Dr. Henry Rose Carter was probably the ablest doctor in the Marine Hospital
Service which has since evolved into the U. S. Public Health Service-
but went back to U. S. in
He was then in charge of the quarantine service in Havana- He was an expert
in yellow fever and a very learned man He was Gorgas's assistant in Panama-- He was a cousin of the Major
Mm Fitzhugh Carter of the regular Medical Corps U. S. Army mentioned below # 15
Dr. H. R. Carter was-
not in Cuba after
July 23, 1900- When
he left for U.S.-
# 14 At-27 Cavajal St. Quemados, named changed later in this year to Gen. Lee
Street- Gen. Lee was immensely popular with the Cubans- He had been
sent to Cuba in 1896 at Consul General at Havana to put a stop to the execution
of Cubans who were U. S. citizens, which he did- The declaration of War
against Spain was held up until Gen. Lee could be brought back from
Havana in 1898-
# 15 see # 13 above
# 16. see carbon copy-
# 17 see " "
# 18 Reed came to Cuba first on March 10, 1900 to look into a
patented process to make a disinfecting fluid out of sea-water called
electrozone- The engineer officer, Major Black, who had charge of
engineer operations in Havana was buying it to sprinkle streets
disinfect cesspools etc. Reed decided that a solution of bleaching
powder would have been cheaper- He went back before the
He was sent
end of the month.
F. Y. Episode
Page 6-
# 18 continued-
Reed came back to Cuba about May 1st 1900 to investigate an
outbreak of fever in Eastern Cuba at Camaguey- He reported
that it was typhoid- His third visit was in June with the
Yellow Fever Board (June 25). He returned to U. S. about
August 2nd 1900. Returned to Cuba Oct. 3. to Havana Oct. 4, 1900-
Back to U. S. Oct. 13- Returned to Cuba Oct- 28- 1900- Finally return-
ed to Washington Feb- 9th or 10th, 1901- Died in Washington Nov. 23, 1902
# 19- The trip to the Philippines was given up- why I do not
know- Reed was a very poor sailor & always sea-sick as long
as he was afloat- I imagine he was not Keen about going-
# 20- Lazear kept track of the y. f. cases and I think Reed
got his data from him- My record in my diary was a casual
one for my own information and not intended to be a complete
official record- The isolation wards were across the R. R. to Playa track
where the Cubans think Camp Lazear was - where Lazear died
and I, & other cases, were treated-
#21- Yes the first five seem from the record to have lived at
20 Gen. Lee Street- The name of 6 was Ocain- He was a teamster
and therefore presumably a hired employe' of the O. M. Dept., not
an enlisted soldier, I dont know where he lived. It was Hambur-
ger who lived at 102 Real St. I dont know where Corp. Walker Co. H
7th Cav lived or the civilian teamster Hoagland- Of course
as you know Major Edmunds lived where I formerly lived
at 27 Gen Lee St. Mrs. Fenn was I think an old woman who
lived across Gen. Lee St from 27 but I am not sure, if so
She was not connected with the Army - but I note that Dr.
Angle's speaks of a Mrs. Muller who had a case across
the street from the “where Dr Kean and his wife suffered a
F. Y. Episode
Page 7-
case of yellow fever”- Angle's has confused us with the case
of Major Edmunds and his wife- I was living at the Hdqrs
on Calzada Real when I was attacked and Mrs Kean was in
New Jersey- I am afraid I cannot help you out in tracing the
progress of the infection- The entry in my diary is casual &
not the official record which was kept by the medical officer
who attended the cases- Dr Peter C. Field was the attending Surgeon
at Hdqrs but he was absent on leave in the U. S. at that
time and I think probably Lazear was doing the work.
# 22 Carter H. C. was plainly an error- It was Henry Rose Carter
I have no objection to your mentioning my visit to Edmund's
house, if you make it clear that I did not go into the house but
sat on the porch and talked to the nurse through the large window
which came down to the floor- So I obeyed the letter but not
the spirit of the order and, as there were only iron bars but no s'ash
in the window, it was easy for the agents of infection to come and
go-
# 23- No I have no recollection of what conversation occurred
between Reed & myself, only the fact of his coming and my
being glad to see him- I do not recollect anything very
distinctly about the occurrences of the first three or four days
Captain Hepburn was in the same tent with me, He was
a Signal Corps Officer and a hard drinker, so the doctors
shook their heads over him- My only alarming symp-
tom as I recollect was bleeding gums for a day or two
I was in one of the tents of the isolation ward across
the Railroad from the Hospital- All of the yellow
fever cases were treated there-
Y. F. Episode
Page 8
# 24- I lived at Columbia Bks after Gen Lee left and the
Military Dept. of Havana & Pinar del Rio was given up & all
Cuba made one Military Department under Gen. Leonard Wood-
I then became the surgeon at Columbia Bks. March. 8, 1901 & lived at the Hospital
until May 24th 1901 when I was relieved from duty at Columbia
Bks and ordered to duty on General Wood's staff as Jifé
de Beneficencia - i. e. in charge of all the Cuban hospitals,
leper hospitals, insane asylum & orphan asylums in
Cuba- Gen Wood then had a nice little cottage built for
me at the upper (north end) of the row of officers quar-
ters at Columbia Bks- I lived there until we established
the Cuban Republic and left for the U. S. May 20 1902-
# 25- My notation in my diary on Sept. 3rd 1900 is "Dr Carroll was
" taken with the fever Saturday 1st or perhaps Friday Aug 31st
" and is in a dangerous condition today- Sept. 7th Dr Carroll
“is much better and nearly out of danger” I understood
that Carroll was entirely skeptical about the role of the
mosquito so much so that he did not observe quarantine
for a week after but went into Havana a day or two after
being bitten,
thus destroying much of the value of his case as an experi-
ment- Reed was very indignant when he learned this-
I do not remember how soon after Dean became sick. I
heard of it- Not as soon as Truby however as my duty
did not take me to the hospital
# 26- Now take note - Gen. Truby is mistaken that Reed
gave me any intimation that Lazear's infection was
an experimental one- I never heard this until Gen
Truby told me here in Washington only a few years ago-
when Reed had been in his grave 35 years or more-
Y. F. Episode
Page 9.
# 27 I put the pencil question mark mark at the
end of the sentence “This probably caused his death”
many years later, when I was reading it over-
probably after Truby told me of his belief-
# 28- I do not thing I can amplify the interview
that Reed & I had with Gen. Wood more or better
than I did in my address on the dedication of his
birthplace which I sent you to read- If you would like
to see it again I can send it.
# 29- I do not see any reason why not- It was more
that 40 years ago-
# 30 I dont know- It may have been that he said on the 7
& arrived on the 10th or it may have been that he left
between those dates-
When I met Moran in Charlottesville it was in the
dining room with a big crowd & many introductions
so I did not have any opportunity to discuss details
of your visit but he spoke of you in terms of admiration-
I have no doubt that you have found the building
no. 1. but I have my doubts if you can arouse any real
interest in making a memorial there, or if it would be
worth the hard work and expenditure of zeal to make
the effort- Such tremendous things are going on in the
world now, that sentimental considerations of no practical
importance will not appeal to people- Your very care-
ful and thorough sifting of all the facts about the
episode itself is another matter- that is history
and is of great importance and value- I will talk
over this with General Ireland and get his reaction-
Y. F. Episode
Page 10
He is a great man with a heart of gold, and is more
of a realist than I am, so his opinion will be great
value if any question arises as to whether we should
open up the frictions and jealousies of Reed's assistants-
It may be that you can placate the jealousies of our
Cuban friends also- It distresses me to have a good
fellow like Angle's talk so foolishly and remember so
inaccurately-
For convenience of reference I have marked the paragraphs
on page 4 & 5 - of your letter, after the 30 questions with
¶ marks continuing the number so as not to confuse
the two-
¶ 33 The date of the attack in La Lucha should be
fixed approximately by the date of the entry in my
diary which is Nov. 23. 1900 - the day after Kissinger
was bitten- I should think it should be certainly
in the issues of the preceding two weeks- But is
it worth the trouble to hunt up this foolish article
when you know what the result was- It brought
everything into the open & saved a lot of trouble in
efforts to keep things quiet.
¶ 34 No I have never seen Hemmeter's article in James-
Is James a medical Journal? If so its files would be
in the Army Medical Library- As to Carroll's being
proud of my putting my hand on the back of his chair
of which I have of course no recollection, you do not realize
the immense social gulf that there was in the old
Army between an enlisted man and an officer
Y. F. Episode
Page 11
and that until not long before this he had been for
years an enlisted man who would never be invited
to any social gathering in an officer's house and would
not even sit down if he came on business- And
Carroll was an Englishman of the laboring class to begin with-
It was'nt that I was such an exalted personage, but
that he was being treated as an equal by a commissioned
Mrs. Carroll
officer that he was boasting of. I have my doubts if she
ever was invited to dinner in an officer's family-
The Army before the World War and especially before
the Spanish War was a real feudal institution, as
the British Navy, & to a less extent our Navy is now-
¶ 35- I do not recollect but I imagine that it wasnt
convenient for me to go to Havana and I asked
him to cash the check. The watch & chain was for
Kissenger- He had declined the bonus of $2.0000 as
Moran did and I suppose his comrades told him
what a fool he was- Meanwhile I had taken part of
his money & ordered the watch & chain to be presented
to him by the Division Chief Surgeon who also made
him a corporal- Then he afterward came to me &
asked if the watch & chain. cost all of $20000
I told him no, that there was about $7000 left.
So he asked if he could have the balance- I said
Yes and gave it to him- That shows the difference
between Kissinger and Moran - who never accepted
a penny of it-
¶ 36- I dont know anything about this-
Y. F. Episode
Page 12 -
¶ 37- My diary shows that he Lazear died at 8 P.M. Sept. 25-
I dont know how these errors crept in-
As to errors in dates I notice that Howard Kelly in
his Life of Walter Reed gives his death as Nov. 22, 1902
but my diary shows that he died at 2.05 a.m. on the
morning of the 23rd- The news spread in the morning that he died
“last night” but it was after midnight-
¶ 38- If you were here with your energy we would do it
today, or tomorrow.
¶ 39 I will do it before the week is out- as far as Dr Angle's
is concerned- P. S. I wrote Angle's Jan 30th-
¶ 40. By doing a little everyday you see I have answer-
ed pretty nearly all your questions-
So I think I will got off the box. I will write
again after Gen. Truby sends me the carbon of
his reply to your answer-
I have a letter from Mr Harry Clemons Librarian Univ
Va. in which he says that you have sent him a
copy of The Mile Post and he has filed in with
“Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
With best wishes for the New Year
div1.closer:
Sincerely Yours J. R. Kean. Hon Elihu Root, Sec'y of War in 1900 spoke in fine terms
of Lazear and the work of the Board in his annual
report to Congress of Dec. 1st 1900- It was in this report
that he recommended Reed to be made a Colonel by
a special provision of the Army Appropriation Bill-
Reed died before it appeared in print- I knew of it and
told Reed of it when he was dying- His reply was “I do not
care for that now-”
Y. F. Episode P. S.
13
Feb 1st 1941
Dear Dr. Hench: Your little bond box is packed and
should have gone yesterday but an accumulation of
small matter which could not wait prevented-
I hope that this collection of detached statements will
help in your patient, persistent search for a true picture.
I was thinking it over while I was dressing this morning.
I agree with General Wood's statement on page 48 of
Senate Doc. 822, that Reed's “was the originating, directing and
controlling mind in this work, and the others were assis-
tants only.” Prof. Welch agrees with this. (same page) and
states that he was “in a position to know”- But the
contributions of the assistants varied greatly in value
and as far as the mosquito work is concerned Lazear
was the only one to contribute materially to the solution
of the problem- Dr. H. R. Carter had made the observations
at Orwood and Taylor, Miss. in 1898 that it took two weeks
to infect a house but less that one to infect a man - or as
Reed expressed it, that was the difference between the
incubation of a primary & a secondary case - but Carter,
clever as he was, could not tell the reason- Lazear whose
trained scientific mind realized the importance of every
detail, made such careful minute records of his operations
that when Reed studied them, he saw like a flash of
light the reason for the failure of the first series of
cases: that the period of what was afterwards called
(I think by Carter) extrinsic incubation had to be fulfilled
before the mosquito because potent for infection-
The lack of this crucial fact explains the failure of Dr.
(over)
15 14.
Finlay's long continued and very intelligent efforts to
produce experimental cases - altho his son tries hard
in his book to make us believe (us he undoubtedly does)
that he did produce a few with erratic periods of incuba-
tion and non-typical symptoms- Just how near Lazear
came to divining the fact of extrinsic incubation I do not
know and we may never know, useless his little notebook
should happily reappear- But it is clear to me that
if Carroll and Agramonte had both died of yellow
fever on the same day with Lazear the problem would
still have been solved just the same- Carroll did
some experiments in infections with filtered blood in the
autumn of 1901, but they added nothing to the Eleven
immortal Conclusions which Reed announced to the
Pan American Med. Congress in Habana Feb. 4, 1901,
which as Dr. F. F. Russell said recently have never
been changed or amended to this day - see Senate Docp. 87
Now Agramonte did as I understend contribute
greatly to the first work of the Board, the wiping off
the slate of the Sanarelli B. icteroides which was a
necessary first step as it had been accepted by
the French Academy of Medicine- And he tried to infect
all the common laboratory animals without success*- He
even persuaded Señora Abren to let him take her
pet chipanzee “Chimpa” to the bed side and gave him
a blood injection from a yellow fever patient- If Naguchi
had studied the records of the Reed Board he would not have
gone off on the false trail, which damaged his reputation
as a scientist and probably cost him his life- I always
said he was wrong-
* It is curious how the names of Army Medical Officers run like red threads thru the history of yellow
fever and malaria It was an Army Med Officer who had gone with F. F. Russell to the Rockefeller Foundation
who discovered later that Asiatic Monkeys were the only animals susceptible to yellow fever Beueewkes was his
name-
white mice can be infected by injection into the brain-
Y. F. Episode
Page 14 - 15
Between Carroll and Agramonte I would believe Agramonte
every time- But I must confess that I never did believe
A. s account of the incident of Dean's infection and the
conversation leading up to it- I have only my general
impression recieved at the time of the circumstances and
can offer nothing in rebuttal: but there is an unreality
about it, just as there is an improbability about the
generally accepted account of Lazear letting himself
be bitten in the ward by a mosquito, whose previous life
he did not know- But Agramonte was a real man,
and Carroll had a yellow streak in him as broad as
your hand (Reed had made for him the opportunity
to study medicine) and attain, what his lower middle class
English soul valued so much, to mix on terms of equality
with “Officers and gentlemen”- Yet he had no more loyalty
to Reed than an alley cat- And his feeling for Lazear
was one of bitterness- When he found that mosquito really
could infect, he complained that Lazear put the whole
bunch on him but only put one on himself-
But we of the Medical Corps who had some inside
knowledge have not undertaken to answer the Hemmeters
or make adjudications of credit but have left it to
distance-in-time to let the smaller men drop out of sight-
It was only when a man of the standing and reputation
of Burton K. Hendrick, backed by the name of Mrs. Gorgas
and sinning against light, undertook to filch some of Reeds
laurels for Gorgas, when the latter had received all the earthly
rewards and Reed none, I took my pen in hand at the request
of the Surgeon General (Ireland) and Mrs Reed and wrote the
review of the Life of Gorgas of which I sent you a copy in the box its first trip.
Sincerely yours
J. R. Kean
